text: That attitude of saying that every problem is our problem and radical accountability and ownership mentality helped us find opportunities that maybe the business wasn't explicitly asking us to solve, but we were able to triangulate why it might be important for the business for us to solve it.
speaker: Chris Miller
context: Lenny asks Chris about the early success factors that helped HubSpot grow. Chris explains how their growth team's mentality of radical accountability—taking ownership of problems regardless of whether they were assigned to them—allowed them to identify and address opportunities that were not initially prioritized by the business. This proactive approach helped them contribute significantly to the company's growth.
text_ko: 모든 문제는 우리 문제라고 생각하고, 철저한 책임감과 주인의식을 가지는 태도가 우리에게 비즈니스가 명시적으로 요구하지 않았던 기회를 찾는 데 큰 도움이 됐어요. 우리가 왜 그 문제를 해결하는 게 비즈니스에 중요할 수 있는지를 잘 파악할 수 있었거든요.
text_zh: 这种将每个问题视为我们自己问题的态度，以及激进的责任感和主人翁意识，帮助我们发现了一些业务可能并没有明确要求我们解决的机会，但我们能够推测出这些问题对业务的重要性。
text_es: Esa actitud de considerar que cada problema es nuestro problema, junto con una mentalidad de responsabilidad radical y de propiedad, nos ayudó a identificar oportunidades que tal vez el negocio no nos estaba pidiendo explícitamente que resolviéramos, pero pudimos triangular por qué podría ser importante para la empresa que nosotros lo solucionáramos.
key_sentence: Radical accountability helped us find opportunities not explicitly asking to be solved.

text: We intentionally put out a lot of free software, and the idea is that this software is not sort of gimmicky. It's not designed to run out of value on day one. It's actually designed so that our smallest customers can get some value out of it in a sustainable way.
speaker: Chris Miller
context: Lenny inquires about HubSpot's approach to product-led growth. Chris discusses their strategy of offering free software that provides genuine value to users, rather than being a gimmick that quickly loses its appeal. This approach aims to engage users meaningfully, prompting them to upgrade as they see the product's benefits.
text_ko: 우리는 의도적으로 많은 무료 소프트웨어를 제공해요. 이 소프트웨어는 단순한 gimmick이 아니고, 첫날부터 가치가 떨어지도록 설계된 게 아니에요. 오히려 가장 작은 고객들도 지속 가능한 방식으로 가치를 얻을 수 있도록 만들어졌어요.
text_zh: 我们故意推出了大量免费的软件，这些软件并不是花哨的 gimmicky 产品。它们并不是在第一天就失去价值，而是旨在让我们最小的客户以可持续的方式获得一些实际的价值。
text_es: Nosotros lanzamos intencionadamente una gran cantidad de software gratuito, y la idea es que este software no sea simplemente un truco (gimmick). No está diseñado para perder su valor desde el primer día. En realidad, está concebido para que nuestros clientes más pequeños puedan obtener un valor sostenible de él.
key_sentence: This software is designed to provide genuine value in a sustainable way.

text: One of the traits that I look for in PMs that I hire onto my teams... is relentless curiosity, this insatiable desire to understand things and a lack of fear in admitting when they don't understand things.
speaker: Chris Miller
context: Lenny asks Chris about the key traits he values in product managers. Chris emphasizes that relentless curiosity is crucial, as it enables PMs to seek understanding and admit gaps in their knowledge. This trait fosters a culture of learning and innovation within teams, allowing them to address complex challenges effectively.
text_ko: 제가 팀에 채용하는 PM들에게서 찾는 특성 중 하나는 바로 끈질긴 호기심이에요. 이해하고자 하는 끝없는 욕구와 모르는 걸 인정하는 데 두려움이 없는 태도죠.
text_zh: 我在招聘项目经理（PM）时，最看重的特质之一就是他们对事物的无尽好奇心，以及在不理解时毫不畏惧地承认自己的不足。
text_es: Una de las características que busco en los PMs (Project Managers) que contrato para mis equipos es una curiosidad incesante, ese deseo insaciable de comprender las cosas y la falta de miedo para admitir cuando no entienden algo.
key_sentence: I look for relentless curiosity and admitting when they don't understand.

text: If you're doing product-led growth the right way, then you're trying to balance the science and sort of taking a somewhat hygienic approach to validating assumptions and hypotheses with being really ambitious.
speaker: Chris Miller
context: Lenny asks Chris about the balance required in product-led growth strategies. Chris explains that successful product-led growth involves a careful balance of scientific rigor and ambition—validating ideas through data while still pushing for impactful innovations. This approach helps teams avoid stagnation while ensuring decisions are data-informed.
text_ko: 제품 주도 성장(product-led growth)을 제대로 하고 있다면, 과학적인 접근을 통해 가설과 가정을 검증하는 것과 동시에 야망을 가지고 균형을 맞추려고 노력하고 있는 거예요.
text_zh: 如果你在正确地进行产品驱动增长（product-led growth），那么你应该在科学性和以一种相对规范的方式验证假设之间找到平衡，同时保持雄心壮志。
text_es: Si estás implementando el crecimiento impulsado por el producto (product-led growth) de la manera correcta, estás tratando de equilibrar la parte científica y adoptando un enfoque bastante metódico para validar supuestos e hipótesis, al mismo tiempo que mantienes una gran ambición.
key_sentence: A hygienic approach balances validating assumptions with being ambitious.

text: It wasn't until I got my second product management job where it really was an inflection point, where I was like, 'Oh, got it. This is what this is supposed to look and feel like.'
speaker: Chris Miller
context: Lenny inquires about Chris's career journey in product management. Chris reflects on how his second role marked a pivotal moment in his career, where he finally grasped the essence of product management by working closely with users and utilizing data to drive decisions. This experience transformed his understanding and approach to the field.
text_ko: 두 번째 제품 관리 직업을 얻었을 때 진짜 전환점이 왔어요. 그때서야 '아, 이게 진짜 이런 느낌이구나' 하고 깨달았어요.
text_zh: 直到我获得第二份产品管理（product management）工作时，我才真正意识到这是一个转折点，那时我心里想：“哦，明白了。这就是它应该呈现和感受的样子。”
text_es: No fue hasta que conseguí mi segundo trabajo en gestión de productos (product management) que realmente fue un punto de inflexión, donde pensé: 'Ah, ya lo entendí. Así es como se supone que debe lucir y sentirse esto.'
key_sentence: My second job was an inflection point; I grasped the essence of product management.

text: If you're a smaller team, you kind of have an acute understanding of the pain points that are like today's buyers that you need to put out.
speaker: Chris Miller
context: Lenny discusses the importance of understanding customer pain points in product-led growth. Chris suggests that smaller teams often have a better grasp of the challenges faced by contemporary buyers. Recognizing these pain points allows companies to tailor their solutions more effectively, enhancing customer engagement and satisfaction.
text_ko: 작은 팀이라면 요즘 구매자들이 겪는 문제점들에 대해 더 잘 이해하고 있을 거예요. 그걸 해결해줘야 하니까요.
text_zh: 如果你是一个小团队，你对当今买家的痛点有着深刻的理解，这些痛点是你需要解决的。
text_es: Si eres un equipo más pequeño, tienes una comprensión aguda de los puntos de dolor que enfrentan los compradores actuales que necesitas abordar.
key_sentence: Smaller teams have an acute understanding of contemporary buyers' pain points.
